net.roydesign.mac
Class MRJAdapter

java.lang.Object
  net.roydesign.mac.MRJAdapter
All Implemented Interfaces:
MRJFolderConstants
public final class MRJAdapter
extends java.lang.Object
implements MRJFolderConstants

This class offers a unique interface to the functionality provided by MRJToolkit with MRJ 1.5, 2.x and 3.x, and com.apple.eawt and com.apple.eio with MRJ 4.x. Some functionality is not present in all versions of MRJ, and this class makes up for it by implementing itself what was missing, ensuring that the methods you use will work on any version of Mac OS, within reason.

The class also contains a collection of methods useful for handling Mac OS specific files (like Info.plist and PkgInfo) and converting Mac OS type codes between Strings and integers. These methods are written to not depend on any Mac OS API to ensure that they can be used on any platform, which could happen for example when handling an application bundle that is temporarily sitting on a machine other than a Mac.

All methods are designed to behave in a sensible manner when used on platforms other than the Mac. Most of the time, this means doing nothing or returning the same exception as they do on the Mac when an error occurs. Where possible, some methods are functional on all platforms. Check the documentation specific to each method to know where they stand. However, if you really need cross-platform functionality then you should use the higher-level classes in net.roydesign.app and net.roydesign.io which essentially integrate this functionality in a more cross-platform way.

Version:
MRJ Adapter 1.2

Constant Field Values

javaVersion

public static float javaVersion
The version of the Java VM.

mrjVersion

public static float mrjVersion
The version of the MRJ VM. When not running on Mac OS, its value will be -1.

useMacBinaryToolkit

public static boolean useMacBinaryToolkit
Whether to try using MacBinary Toolkit in the method openFileResourceFork(). This is true by default. If MacBinary Toolkit is not available, it will be set to false automatically after the first call to that method.

useBrowserLauncher

public static boolean useBrowserLauncher
Whether to try using BrowserLauncher in the method openURL(). This is true by default. If BrowserLauncher is not available, it will be set to false automatically after the first call to that method.

Method Detail

setFileType

public static void setFileType(java.io.File file,
                               java.lang.String type)
                        throws java.io.IOException
Set the Mac OS type code of the given file. This method does nothing on other platforms. The type code is a case-sensitive four character string. Any exceeding character will be ignored and the string will be padded with spaces if shorter, with the exception of the case where the string length is zero, in which case the file type will be set to nothing.

Parameters:
file - the file to set the type of
type - the type code
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

getFileType

public static java.lang.String getFileType(java.io.File file)
                                    throws java.io.IOException
Get the Mac OS type code of the given file. On other platforms, this method returns an empty string, which is the same as if the file type was not set on the Mac platform. A Mac type is a four character string, unless the file has no type, in which case an empty string is returned. Note that this method supports Mac OS style bundles on all platforms, which is useful in the case where such a bundle is temporarily located on a non-Mac file system. When this is detected, the method will extract the type code from the bundle just like Mac OS does natively.

Parameters:
file - the file to get to type from
Returns:
the type code
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

setFileCreator

public static void setFileCreator(java.io.File file,
                                  java.lang.String creator)
                           throws java.io.IOException
Set the Mac OS creator code of the given file. This method does nothing on other platforms. The creator code is a case-sensitive four character string. Any exceeding character will be ignored and the string will be padded with spaces if shorter, with the exception of the case where the string length is zero, in which case the file creator will be set to nothing.

Parameters:
file - the file to set the creator of
creator - the creator code
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

A Mac creator is a four character string, unless the file has no creator, in which case an empty string is returned. Note that this method supports Mac OS style bundles on all platforms, which is useful in the case where such a bundle is temporarily located on a non-Mac file system. When this is detected, the method will extract the creator code from the bundle just like Mac OS does natively.

setFileCreatorAndType

public static void setFileCreatorAndType(java.io.File file,
                                         java.lang.String creator,
                                         java.lang.String type)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
Set the Mac OS creator and type codes of the given file. This method does nothing on other platforms. The creator and type codes are case-sensitive four character strings. Any exceeding character will be ignored and the string will be padded with spaces if shorter, with the exception of the case where the string length is zero, in which case the file creator will be set to nothing.

Parameters:
file - the file to set the creator and type of
creator - the creator code
type - the type code
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

setFileLastModified

public static boolean setFileLastModified(java.io.File file,
                                          long time)
Set the date and time of last modification of the given file. MRJ used to implement this functionality because the File class in Java 1.1 didn't. This method will use File.setLastModified() when running in Java 1.2 or better, on any platform. When running in Java 1.1 on a non-Mac platform, this method will return false.

Parameters:
file - the file to set the creator and type of
time - the new modification time, measured in milliseconds since the epoch (00:00:00 GMT, January 1, 1970)
Returns:
whether the operation succeeded or not

findFolder

public static java.io.File findFolder(short domain,
                                      int type,
                                      boolean create)
                               throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
Find a special Mac OS folder. This method locates on disk a folder designated by the OS for a specific purpose. For example, this can be the Preferences folder or the Desktop folder. Sometimes such folders exist in multiple versions for different contexts, which is why the method requires a domain to be specified. Most of the time, you will want to use the value MRJFolderConstants.kUserDomain. Then you have to specify the type of the folder that you're looking for. Each such folder is identified by a unique code. If there is no constant defined in MRJFolderConstants for the folder you're looking for then you should use the other form of this method which takes a string. This method throws a FileNotFoundException on other platforms, which is the same as what this method does on Mac OS when the folder can't be found.

Parameters:
domain - the domain of the folder
type - the type constant of the folder to find
create - whether to create the folder if it doesn't already exist
Returns:
the special folder object, or null
Throws:
java.io.FileNotFoundException - when the folder can't be found

findFolder

public static java.io.File findFolder(short domain,
                                      java.lang.String type,
                                      boolean create)
                               throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
Find a special Mac OS folder. This method locates on disk a folder designated by the OS for a specific purpose. For example, this can be the Preferences folder or the Desktop folder. Sometimes such folders exist in multiple versions for different contexts, which is why the method requires a domain to be specified. Most of the time, you will want to use the value MRJFolderConstants.kUserDomain. Then you have to specify the type of the folder that you're looking for. Each such folder is identified by a unique code. Just like file types and creators, this code is four characters long and case sensitive. If there's a constant defined in MRJFolderConstants for the folder you're looking for then you should use the other form of this method. Otherwise, pass the type as a string. The format of the type code will be normalized to be four-characters long if it isn't already. Look in Folders.h of the Carbon interfaces for possible values to be passed. This method throws a FileNotFoundException on other platforms.

Parameters:
domain - the domain of the folder
type - the type code of the folder to find
create - whether to create the folder if it doesn't already exist
Returns:
the special folder object\
Throws:
java.io.FileNotFoundException - when the folder can't be found

findApplication

public static java.io.File findApplication(java.lang.String idOrCreator)
                                    throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
Find a specific Mac OS application. This method locates on disk an application given its bundle identifier (e.g. com.apple.Safari) or creator code (e.g. R*ch). Note that creator codes are always four characters long and case sensitive. The format of the creator code will be normalized to be four-characters long if it isn't already. This method throws a FileNotFoundException on other platforms, which is the same as what this method does on Mac OS when the folder can't be found.

Parameters:
idOrCreator - the bundle identifier or creator code of the application to find
Returns:
the application file object
Throws:
java.io.FileNotFoundException - when the application can't be found

getBundleResource

public static java.io.File getBundleResource(java.lang.String resource)
                                      throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
Get a resource file from the application bundle. Resource files are stored in the folder Contents/Resources inside the bundle. This method will locate the requested resource only if it's located at the top level of the Resources folder. It returns a File object that can be used to read the resource. This method throws a FileNotFoundException on other platforms, which is the same as what this method does on Mac OS when the resource can't be found.

Parameters:
resource - the name of the resource file
Returns:
the resource file
Throws:
java.io.FileNotFoundException - when the resource can't be found

getBundleResource

public static java.io.File getBundleResource(java.lang.String resource,
                                             java.lang.String subFolder)
                                      throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
Get a resource file from the application bundle. Resource files are stored in the folder Contents/Resources inside the bundle. This method will locate the requested resource only if it's located in the specified subfolder of the Resources folder. It returns a File object that can be used to read the resource. This method throws a FileNotFoundException on other platforms, which is the same as what this method does on Mac OS when the resource can't be found.

Parameters:
resource - the name of the resource file
subFolder - the name of the subfolder of Resources
Returns:
the resource file
Throws:
java.io.FileNotFoundException - when the resource can't be found

openFileResourceFork

public static java.io.InputStream openFileResourceFork(java.io.File file)
                                                throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
Open the Mac OS resource fork of the given file. The resource fork is returned as a new unbuffered InputStream, which can be accessed and read in the usual way. This method is functional as is on Mac OS X. On classic Mac OS and other platforms, it can only be functional if Gregory Guerin's excellent MacBinary Toolkit <http://www.amug.org/~glguerin> is installed. Note that MacBinary Toolkit will also be used on Mac OS X, if it's available. Set useMacBinaryToolkit to false to turn off this behavior. Finally, resource forks are a feature specific to HFS (Mac) file systems, but this method also recognizes a common scheme of other systems used as file servers which store resource forks in a subdirectory named .HSResource. If the file resource fork doesn't exist or can't be opened, the method throws a FileNotFoundException.

Parameters:
file - the file for which to open the resource fork
Returns:
a new unbuffered input stream to read the resource fork
Throws:
java.io.FileNotFoundException - when the resource fork can't be opened

openURL

public static void openURL(java.lang.String url)
                    throws java.io.IOException
Open the given URL in the application that is bound to the specified protocol. While this method can in theory handle 'file' URLs, the DocumentFile.open() method is preferred. This method is functional as is on classic Mac OS and Mac OS X. On other platforms, it can only be functional if Eric Albert's excellent BrowserLauncher <http://browserlauncher.sourceforge.net> is installed. Note that BrowserLauncher will also be used on classic Mac OS and Mac OS X, if it's available. Set useBrowserLauncher to false to turn off this behavior. This method throws an IOException if opening URLs is not supported on the current platform, which is the same as what this method does on Mac OS when the URL can't be opened.

Parameters:
url - the URL string to be opened
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

public static boolean isAboutAutomaticallyPresent()
Get whether the About menu item is automatically present in the menu bar of the current underlying platform.

Returns:
whether the About menu item is automatically present

isPreferencesEnabled

public static boolean isPreferencesEnabled()
Get whether the Preferences menu item is enabled or not. This menu item is automatically provided by the OS on Mac OS X. On classic Mac OS and other platforms, this method always returns false.

Returns:
whether the Preferences menu item is enabled

isAppleJDirectAvailable

public static boolean isAppleJDirectAvailable()
Check whether Apple's JDirect API is available in the underlying platform. Note that there are multiple versions of JDirect with implementation differences. If you require a specific version of JDirect, use the getAppleJDirectVersion() method instead.

Returns:
whether Apple's JDirect API is available

getAppleJDirectVersion

public static int getAppleJDirectVersion()
Get the version of Apple's JDirect API implemented by the underlying platform. If Apple's JDirect is unavailable, this method returns -1.

Returns:
the version of Apple's JDirect implementation

isAppleClassicVM

public static boolean isAppleClassicVM()
Check whether the Java VM currently used is based on Apple's classic implementation, corresponding to Java 1.1 on Mac OS 9 and prior.

Returns:
whether Apple's classic VM implementation is in use

isAppleCarbonVM

public static boolean isAppleCarbonVM()
Check whether the Java VM currently used is based on Apple's Carbon implementation, corresponding to Java 1.3 on Mac OS X.

Returns:
whether Apple's Carbon VM implementation is in use

isAppleCocoaVM

public static boolean isAppleCocoaVM()
Check whether the Java VM currently used is based on Apple's Cocoa implementation, corresponding to Java 1.4 on Mac OS X.

Returns:
whether Apple's Cocoa VM implementation is in use

isAWTUsingScreenMenuBar

public static boolean isAWTUsingScreenMenuBar()
Check whether AWT uses the screen menu bar or not. This will only return true on Mac OS. This method always returns false on other platforms.

Returns:
whether AWT uses the screen menu bar

isSwingUsingScreenMenuBar

public static boolean isSwingUsingScreenMenuBar()
Check whether Swing uses the screen menu bar or not. This will only return true on Mac OS when the Mac-specific look and feel is used and the appropriate system properties are set that activate the frameless menu bar. This method always returns false on other platforms.

Returns:
whether Swing uses the screen menu bar

setFramelessMenuBar

public static void setFramelessMenuBar(java.awt.MenuBar menuBar)
Set the AWT frameless menu bar. This menu bar is shown when no frame is visible. This state is normal for a Mac application whereas Java doesn't have any built-in way to do this because its menu bars must be attached to frames. On platforms other than Mac OS and Mac OS X, this method sets the menu bar internally so that it will be properly returned by a subsequent call to getFramelessMenuBar().

Parameters:
menuBar - the AWT menu bar to use as frameless menu bar

getFramelessMenuBar

public static java.awt.MenuBar getFramelessMenuBar()
Get the AWT frameless menu bar. This method is functional on all platforms.

Returns:
the AWT frameless menu bar

setFramelessJMenuBar

public static void setFramelessJMenuBar(javax.swing.JMenuBar menuBar)
Set the Swing frameless menu bar. This menu bar is shown when no frame is visible. This state is normal for a Mac application whereas Java doesn't have any built-in way to do this because its menu bars must be attached to frames. Note that this method won't have any visual effect if the application doesn't use the Mac-specific look and feel and if the appropriate system properties are not set that activate the screen menu bar. Also, on platforms other than Mac OS and Mac OS X, this method sets the menu bar internally so that it will be properly returned by a subsequent call to getFramelessMenuBar().

Parameters:
menuBar - the Swing menu bar to use as frameless menu bar

getFramelessJMenuBar

public static javax.swing.JMenuBar getFramelessJMenuBar()
Get the Swing frameless menu bar. This method is functional on all platforms.

Returns:
the Swing frameless menu bar

fourCharCodeToInt

public static int fourCharCodeToInt(java.lang.String code)
Convert a four character code string to an integer. This method will normalize the given string in one of two ways. If the length of the string is zero, it will return the integer value 0, which provides support for unsetting entirely the creator or type of a file. On the other hand, if the given string is longer than zero, then it will be normalized to a length of four characters before being converted to an integer. If the string is too long it will be truncated and if it's too short it will be padded with spaces.

Parameters:
code - the four character code string
Returns:
the four character code as an integer

intToFourCharCode

public static java.lang.String intToFourCharCode(int code)
Convert a four character code integer to a string. This method will normalize the returned string in one of two ways. If the given integer is zero, then an empty string will be returned, which provides support for files that do not have a creator or type. Otherwise, the given integer is unpacked into a string with a length of four.

Parameters:
code - the four character code integer
Returns:
the four character code as a string

parsePkgInfo

public static java.lang.String parsePkgInfo(java.io.File file,
                                            java.lang.String key)
                                     throws java.io.IOException
Utility method to read and parse the content of the given Mac OS PkgInfo file, trying to extract the value of the given key. The method only supports two keys, "type" and "creator", since that's the only info that can be found in the PkgInfo file. If the given key is not found, the value null is returned.

Parameters:
file - the PkgInfo file
key - the key to look for
Returns:
the value of the key, or null
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

parseInfoPlist

public static java.lang.String parseInfoPlist(java.io.File file,
                                              java.lang.String key)
                                       throws java.io.IOException
Utility method to read and parse the content of the given Mac OS Info.plist file, trying to extract the value of the given key. The keys that can be found in the Info.plist are defined by Apple. If the given key is not found, the value null is returned.

Parameters:
file - the Info.plist file
key - the key to look for
Returns:
the value of the key, or null
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

parseMRJAppProperties

public static java.lang.String parseMRJAppProperties(java.io.File file,
                                                     java.lang.String key)
                                              throws java.io.IOException
Utility method to read and parse the content of the given Mac OS MRJApp.properties file, trying to extract the value of the given key. The keys that can be found in the Info.plist are defined by Apple. If the given key is not found, the value null is returned.

Parameters:
file - the MRJApp.properties file
key - the key to look for
Returns:
the value of the key, or null
Throws:
java.io.IOException - when an I/O error occurs

getStartupDisk

public static java.lang.String getStartupDisk()
                                       throws java.io.IOException
Get the name of the startup disk. This method will return the name of the startup disk, whether you are running on classic Mac OS or Mac OS X. On all other platforms, it throws an IOException.

Returns:
the name of the startup disk
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs
